content.description:
Extremely short approach. Chill slabby routes. Close  
 to beaches. Ideal hammock trees and sun tanning  
 rocks. What’s there not to like? This whole crag is a  
 10-15m rock cut on the old Columbia and Western  
 Railway which is now part of the Trans Canada Trail.  
 The super civilized approach cuts down on the ticks  
 and poison ivy that plague some of the other Gilpin  
 crags. If you don’t feel like leading, the top of the  
 routes are easily accessible by scrambling climbers  
 right. It’s the most convenient beginners’ crag in the  
 area. It faces south but trees shade it in the evening  
 so it isn’t as scorchingly hot as some of the other  
 south facing Gilpin crags. Make sure to keep your  
 gear off the rail trail because it gets a fair amount of  
 bike traffic.
